Detailed Description

Database query interface.

Description

To make the results from different databases compatible with the same set of generic methods all databases that return a database query return it in a class that fits to this protocol.

Using a formatter on indervidual fetch() calls

You may optionally attach a formatter that will process your results before they are returned. But only on the fetch() calls the formatter is attached to: 

 $f = new CMFormatter(array(
        'created' => 'timestamp|F j, Y, g:i a',
        'cost' => 'number|fixed=2|thousands=,|pre=$'
      ));
      
 $q = $dbh->query("select * from mytable where cost>? and productname=?",
                  array(100, 'Magic Carpet'));     // bind values
 
 // retrive, format and return the next result row
 while($r = $q->fetch('assoc', $f)) {
   print_r($r);
 }
 
 // Array
 // (
 //     [productname] => Magic Carpet
 //     [colour] => Blue
 //     [created] => March 5, 2010, 3:35 pm
 //     [cost] => $450.00
 // )
 // Array
 // (
 //     [productname] => Magic Carpet
 //     [colour] => Green
 //     [created] => March 10, 2010, 11:52 am
 //     [cost] => $429.00
 // )

Alternativly you can attach the formatter to the query so that allow rows are passed through the same formatter. See Using a Formatter

Author:
Elliot Chance

Member Function Documentation

affectedRows (  ) 

Returns the number of affected rows in this query.

If this query did not affect any rows 0 is returned.

Returns:
The number of rows affected by this query.

Implemented in CMMySQLQuery, CMOracleQuery, and CMPostgreSQLQuery.

availableMethods (  ) 

Get available methods.

This method works in the same way availableMethods() for CMDatabaseProtocol works.

 $q = $dbh->query("select * from mytable");
 $features = $q->availableMethods();
 if(!in_array($features, 'fetch'))
   die("We can't read the result!");
Returns:
An array of method names.

Implemented in CMMySQLQuery, CMOracleQuery, and CMPostgreSQLQuery.

fetch ( $  rowMode = 'assoc',
$  formatter = false 
)

Return the next result row from the query as an associative array.

Once all the rows in the result set have been interated false is returned.

 $q = $dbh->query("select * from mytable");
 while($r = $q->fetch()) {
   print_r($r);
 }
Parameters:
$rowMode How each row is converted into an array.

'assoc' Associative array. This is the default
'line' Non-associative array.
'pair' First and second column become key-value.
'cell' Only use the first column.
$formatter Attach an optional CMFormatter.
Returns:
The return value(s) and type(s) depend on the arguments given.

Implemented in CMMySQLQuery, CMOracleQuery, and CMPostgreSQLQuery.

fetchAll ( $  rowMode = 'assoc',
$  direction = 'horizontal',
$  formatter = false 
)

Fetch all rows.

An example of using 'vertical' row direction and 'cell' to get a single array of IDs: 

 $dbh = new CMMySQL("mysql://root:abc123/test");
 $q = $dbh->query("select id from mytable limit 5");
 $ids = $q->fetchAll('cell', 'vertical'); // $ids = array(1, 5, 7, 9, 10)

Or shorten the above code into a single line: 

 $dbh = new CMMySQL("mysql://root:abc123/test");
 $ids = $dbh->query("select id from mytable limit 5")->fetchAll('cell', 'vertical');
Parameters:
$rowMode How each row is converted into an array.

'assoc' Associative array. This is the default
'line' Non-associative array.
'pair' First and second column become key-value.
'cell' Only use the first column.
$direction Fetching direction.

'horizontal' Each row is appended to the return array. This is the default
'vertical' All the rows are appended in a single linear array.
'single' Only use the first row.
$formatter Applies a formatting option to all of the cells in the result set.
See also:
fetch()
CMFormatter::format()

Implemented in CMMySQLQuery, CMOracleQuery, and CMPostgreSQLQuery.

success (  ) 

Check if the query was successful.

Returned if the database engine that created the query handle was unable to execute the query. You can see the last error with CMQueryProtocol::error() like; 

 $q = $dbh->query("select * from mytable"); // mytable does not exist
 if($q->success)
  die("Failed: " . $q->error());

CMQueryProtocol::$QueryFailed is an alias for false for compatibility and ease of use. Hence, the above example is the same as;

 $q = $dbh->query("select * from mytable"); // mytable does not exist
 if(!$q)
  die("Failed: " . $q->error());

 // mytable does not exist
 $q = $dbh->query("select * from mytable") or die("Failed: " . $q->error());

Implemented in CMMySQLQuery, CMOracleQuery, and CMPostgreSQLQuery.

totalRows (  ) 

Total number of rows in the result set.

If the query failed then 0 is returned.

Returns:
The number of rows in the result set.

Implemented in CMMySQLQuery, CMOracleQuery, and CMPostgreSQLQuery.
